content:
#1 : the emergency string ( "Alarm", "Emergency", or "Priority")  are confusing (at first read "Alarm" was not an emergency for me, it was a "simple" alarm) and finally it's nothing else than a boollean

 - use only one string for emergency (ou a boolean)
 - or use an emergency level (0,1,2,...)
would be clearer

#2 : Alfter reading this part : 
-----------------------------
"You have to go to the alarm closest to you (in a direct line), except if it is an emergency alarm, then you have to go there first. If more than one emergency alarm goes off, then you go to the nearest emergency alarm.

EXAMPLE
Input
0 0
3
3 4 Emergency
4 2 Alarm
1 1

Output
4.5"
-----------------------------
my reaction was : "What ? what's that 4.5 value ? it's not even an alarm coordinate ?!"

The first part of the text seems to mean "find the next alarm to go to" and reality is "find distance to the next alarm to go to"




All of that was written in Input and Ouput parts, but when you first read statement, it's not clear

✅ Approved the contribution.
Comment: All seem clear an doable

✅ Approved the contribution.
Comment: The statement is challenging, but clear. Definitely gives a challenge, but good formulation makes up for it.

✅ Approved the contribution.
Comment: Interesting problem. The puzzle is well-crafted.
I think it would be okay for reverse.  Hard, but okay.

There is this description in the input

*If there is an emergency, emergency will be either "True", "true", "1", "yes" or "hurry". If no emergency it will be empt*

but in the example and in the test cases it is "Emergency" and "Alarm"

It caused me some confusion.  Perhaps it would be more clear to simply say that if anything is given after the coordinates then it is an emergency

Also, if you don't want to deal with decimals, you could ask for the square of the distance ;)

There is a funny/tragic story to this contribution.

Fact is that I wrote it while admitted to the hospital. 

In the hospital you could pull on a string and a small sound and red visual cue would signal to the nurse that you needed help.

I saw the nurses press a green button next to a red one (with the visual cue) to shut off the alarm.

The at one point, the red button besides the green one was more convenient for me to push than pulling on the string, so I pressed it.

In a matter of seconds, there were 5 nurses rushing in, so apparently that button was a real emergency, where everyone drops whatever they are doing to help :) I apologized...

Good thing was, it gave me the idea for this clash.
If I got this problem on reverse mode I would personally lose my mind

It's a nice one.  I liked it.  The wordy thing is pleasant because it sets some context and makes it less boring.  Anyway, we all have to filter requirements to find the relevant info ;-) 

The only thing to shorten is the redundant formula.  Just give the distance in the example: for those not familiar you have anyway the formula later on.  

I'd suggest to make the first example more relevant and have 2 alarms, one with and one without emergency.
I made this a lot more wordy than i normally like for clashes. Let me know if I should just drop the backstory
This might be too hard for reverse, let me know what you think. Maybe the first test is clue enough, but it might require you to be familiar with simple trigonometry.

I think reverse is ok: it's not the first one where we recognize an initial position and distance.  It would be important however to "normalize" the "emergency" string to a single value.  

I find it frustrating for the shortest,  because there is formatting, there is math,  there are alogorithms,  and there is parsing.  For any language that needs to import standard library, the imports are a huge overhead.  But maybe I'm  it'd be worth to know what others think about this

Thanks, I see what you mean. Good points...

I will remove the formula and only keep the example.

I will change the example in the Goal to one where there are emergencies included.

Can't have that ;)

What if the output had to include the word distance or maybe closest like:
distance: 5.0

and then go from 5 different emergency states to 3 without the "1" like:
"Emergency", "Alarm", "Priority"

This way the output helps with understanding the reverse. 

I do like the idea of more than one word for the emergency, because in shortest mode you might be tempted to create a variable with a list of emergency words, but if you think about it, you don't have to. I think especially the "1" is very confusing for reverse.

Thx, changed the 
*If there is an emergency, emergency will be either "True", "true", "1", "yes" or "hurry". If no emergency it will be empt*

to: *emergency will be either "Alarm", "Emergency", or "Priority"*

The idea behind using one decimal place is to use real rounding for the shortest
Probably not winning shortest :) But then again thats just the nature of the language.

Thank you, I see your points.

I will change the text to make it clear that it is the "distance"

The primary reason for using words rather than a number for alarms is that it helps understanding what to do in Reverse mode. Understanding that all alarms/emergencies are the same is part of the concept.

I will move the description of the different emergencies to the Goal to make it clear from the beginning. Good idea.

Thank you for your feedback.

Thanks for the comment.

I do mostly Python here, so I would also be interested in comments on possible improvements to be more inclusive of different languages, to make it fun for all.

I included multiple disciplines because of the shortest. I find shortest more fun if things are not too straightforward like a simple formula. 

But let me know any suggestions to lessen the imports.
